            By 
Eliza Collins

09/22/15, 04:52 PM EDT
In a campaign cycle that is all about what you say and how you say it, there’s a new guy in town, and he might be the most honest of all. 
Represent.us, a bipartisan advocacy group working to reform the influence of money in politics, released a parody campaign ad for a fake candidate named "Gil Fulbright" on Monday. It’s the first video in a series of installments of a faux campaign the organization plans to carry on through Election Day. One video will be released every month.
“Other candidates may beat around the bush (or Clinton — whatever you’re into), but I’m here to keep things honest: I owe my entire political career to special interests and lobbyists, and if elected, I’ll spend my presidency paying them back while screwing over the American people,” he says in his announcement. “Like most politicians, I’ll exploit a broken system and sell you out to keep my campaign funded — but at least I’ll sell you out to your face.”
The video — which features “Honest Gil,” played by actor Frank L. Ridley, doing classic campaign-style things while being unusually candid about his motives — has already garnered 1 million views through various websites, according to represent.us.
“I may not be qualified to be president, but a dramatic camera angle can make me look like a president,” Gil says on the video as a montage of him talking with people and pointing into the distance plays. “A president with the conviction to nod, the courage to point and the experience to cram buzzwords into everything I — jobs.” 
Gil “ran” in Kentucky senator's race against Mitch McConnell and Alison Lundergan Grimes in 2014, with a similar campaign. 
Since the video was released on Sunday, his “campaign” has raised more than $25,000 for Represent.us — halfway toward the goal the group had set to accomplish over 50 days. 
“It’s really to shine a light on how American politics really work and I think that’s why it’s resonating so much,” Represent.us director Josh Silver told POLITICO. “In some ways, it's similar to the way Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders are resonating with primary voters ... they’re both calling out the corrupt, money-driven political system and it's resonating with voters.” 
Gil’s campaign ads are just one of the ways Represent.us will reach out to Americans. They’ll also send Ridley — who has appeared in “Orange is The New Black” and “House of Cards” — to the New Hampshire primaries “to do some antics,” according to Silver.
“The issue of money and politics is the most critical domestic political crisis of our time. It’s because money is blocking progress on nearly every issue in government,” Silver said. “Regardless of whether you care about liberal or conservative issues, it’s not the best ideas that are progressing, it is those with the deepest pockets.” 
Represent.us wants to get states to add anti-corruption ballot measures. The most promising so far is “The South Dakota Government Accountability and Anti-Corruption Act,” which is "a proposal to prevent political bribery, improve transparency, and increase enforcement of South Dakota’s ethics laws.”
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Parody candidate raises $25,000 for anti-corruption campaign
